sentences.text: Add OK or FAIL after other browsers where you have tested this issue:
What steps will reproduce the problem?
4. Click Tools / Delete Browser History.  Delete ALL.
1. Start IE8 in InPrivate mode (use -private command line)
Expect: Database entries created InPrivate are deleted.

ChromeFrame and/or Gears should respect the user's privacy preferences and 
actions.
(No comment was entered for this change.)
(No comment was entered for this change.)

It seems to me that the root cause of this issue is that users expect that modifying 
MSIE settings also affects Chrome Frame.
Currently, this is not true afaik;

Chrome 
Frame has its own separate settings.

I don't even 
know how to change Chrome Frame settings;
I have yet to find the UI for that.

If Chrome Frame has no configuration screen of its own, we may want to try and use 
the MSIE settings, so the user can at least modify some of Chrome Frame's settings 
through MSIE settings and Chrome Frame behaves the same as MSIE normally would.

If Chrome Frame has a configuration screen (or one is planned to be added in the 
future), we could consider allowing the user to tell Chrome Frame to use MSIE 
settings where applicable or to use separate settings (with the default being use 
MSIE settings, as that will probably be what most users expect).
I'm not sure this is a bug: the "issue" seems to be by design.

I see this more as a 
feature request to change our design;

I'll let people who know more about the design 
decisions decide.
Leaving as Pri-1 security issue for now.
See also issue 23006: Chrome Frame links circumvent IE8's SmartScreen.

This should not be an issue for cookies and history since Chrome Frame uses IE's 
network stack.

The 'Database' feature, however, is independent of the network stack and is browser 
specific.
> I'm not sure this is a bug: the "issue" seems to be by design.
Regardless of the cause of the issue, we should align our behavior with user expectations.

For example, our incognito home screen warns that plug-ins might persist data, but we'd prefer that they 
respected our privacy settings too.

I haven't looked at the IE InPrivate UI, but I suspect there are similar issues 
with other plug-ins (e.g.

If it's technically feasible for us to respect IE's privacy settings, 
we should definitely do it.
Thanks for filing this and pointing us to IDeleteBrowsingHistory.

@slightlyoff : Will chromeframe inherit IE privacy features or will operate under 
settings of the new content settings in chrome.

If it depends on content settings 
and if that is what is intended, then we can close this one.

@inferno: we're working on respecting IE's settings and user intent insofar as 
possible.

We currently respect InPrivate filtering, are dropping the double-storage of 
cookies, and are working on cache clearing via IDeleteBrowsingHistory.

In the same 
CL I'm moving the chrome profile directory into the IE cache folder so that users who 
clear their cache on browsers < IE 8 will see their GCF history deleted (assuming that 
GCF isn't running at the time).

Chrome privacy controls will not be surfaced initially but it's something we can 
consider for the future;

however it's not clear that we'd have a natural or even 
workable place to add new UI for managing those preferences.
The following revision refers to this bug:
Implements IDeleteBrowsing history and moves the GCF profile into the IE TIF directory for non-priv mode users on IE < 8.
Earlier work enabled InPrivate browsing detection and mapped it to creation of an incognito profile instance.Privacy features and how they operate with this change:
IE 6 & 7: all history (including databases) is deleted if cache is cleared *WITHOUT* an active Chrome process holding references to the profile resources.
If GCF is rendering a page when the cache is cleared, history *WILL NOT* be deleted on the GCF side, however GCF will continue to operate and IE will remove all other history artifacts as usual.
IE 8: GCF cache is cleared in alignment with the options specified by the user.
Clearing Temporary Internet Files may destroy the profile entirely, and so we need to consider not moving the GCF profile on IE 8.
IE 8 (only): pages rendered in GCF *after* entering InPrivate mode are not persisted to disk (use an incognito wrapper on the specified profile).
Currently displayed pages are not effected by the switch, although refreshing them will invoke the new behavior.
Generally speaking, BHO's are disabled by IE 8 while in InPrivate mode, so entering this state is wonky to begin with but we handle it as well as can be expected.
TEST=On IE 8, clear the cache entirely, note GCF entries in DbgView (better tests coming)
I only realized that the above commit message was out of date after it was submitted.

On IE 8 the profile is NOT moved, instead we implement IDeleteBrowsingHistory in the
BHO and clear caches when asked to.
The following revision refers to this bug:
Reverting this CL to see if this fixes chrome frame unit test failures.
Revert 42684 - Implements IDeleteBrowsing history and moves the GCF profile into the IE TIF directory for nonpriv mode users on IE < 8.
Earlier work enabled InPrivate browsing detection and mapped it to creation of an incognito profile instance.Privacy features and how they operate with this change:
IE 6 & 7: all history (including databases) is deleted if cache is cleared *WITHOUT* an active Chrome process holding references to the profile resources.
If GCF is rendering a page when the cache is cleared, history *WILL NOT* be deleted on the GCF side, however GCF will continue to operate and IE will remove all other history artifacts as usual.
IE 8: GCF cache is cleared in alignment with the options specified by the user.
Clearing Temporary Internet Files may destroy the profile entirely, and so we need to consider not moving the GCF profile on IE 8.
IE 8 (only): pages rendered in GCF *after* entering InPrivate mode are not persisted to disk (use an incognito wrapper on the specified profile).
Currently displayed pages are not effected by the switch, although refreshing them will invoke the new behavior.
Generally speaking, BHO's are disabled by IE 8 while in InPrivate mode, so entering this state is wonky to begin with but we handle it as well as can be expected.
TEST=On IE 8, clear the cache entirely, note GCF entries in DbgView (better tests coming)

@bayden - would you like to provide any credit details (name / affiliation) for our 
Chrome Frame release notes?
The following revision refers to this bug:
Re-submit of GCF privacy patch in:
But this time with unittests that pass.
TEST=run unit tests, clear caches, see original CL for more details
The following revision refers to this bug:
TEST=On IE 8, clear the cache entirely, watch GCF launch (via task manager)

title: ChromeFrame does not respect IE Privacy features
